text: hi everyone welcome to IGCSE study buddy
where you can revise biology topics from
the Cambridge IGCSE syllabus
if you are enjoying these videos so far
please don't forget to hit the like
button and subscribe to my channel
this video summarizes part 2 of chapter
9 transport in animals
in the previous video we spoke about the
heart now let's learn about blood
vessels
blood vessels are tubes through which
blood circulates in the body
there are three types of blood vessels
arteries
veins
and capillaries
let's dive into the structure of
arteries
arteries carry blood away from the heart
they carry oxygenated blood except for
the pulmonary artery
blood flows very fast in arteries
they have thick muscular walls to
withstand blood being carried at high
pressures
the walls of arteries also have elastic
fibers so that they can stretch when the
blood passes through
the Lumen is the inside Space of the
artery they have a narrow Lumen to
maintain high blood pressure
they don't have valves since high blood
pressures prevent backflow
so once again arteries carry blood away
from the heart they carry oxygenated
blood except for the pulmonary artery
blood flows fast in arteries
they have thick muscular walls to
withstand blood being carried at high
pressures
artery walls have elastic fibers
they have a narrow Lumen and there are
no valves in arteries
now let's look at the structure of veins
veins carry blood towards the heart
they carry deoxygenated blood except for
the pulmonary vein
blood flows slowly in veins
they have thin muscular walls thick
muscles are not required since blood is
carried at low pressure
the walls of veins have little elastic
fibers since not much is required for
the low blood pressure
veins have a large lumen
valves are present in veins to prevent
blood backflow
one more time veins carry blood towards
the heart they carry deoxygenated blood
except for the pulmonary vein
blood flows slow in veins
they have thin muscular walls with
little elastic fibers
they have a large lumen
and valves are present in veins
let's compare an artery to a vein an
artery has thicker muscular walls with
elastic fibers while a vein has thinner
walls
the lumen in an artery is also narrower
than that of a vein also valves are
present in veins unlike arteries
next let's learn about the function of
capillaries
capillaries are the smallest of blood
vessels that connect arteries and veins
capillaries carry blood to and from the
body's cells
the role of capillaries is to provide an
exchange of oxygen nutrients and waste
products between the blood and the
body's cells
so capillaries supply all cells with
their requirements and take away their
waste products
the structure of capillaries makes them
very well suited for this function
as capillaries are only one cell thick
and have very thin permeable walls this
means that substances can diffuse out of
them very easily
fluid leaks out of the capillaries and
bathes the surrounding cells this is
called tissue fluid
useful substances such as oxygen and
food diffuse out of the blood in the
capillaries into the tissue fluid where
it is then taken to the cells
waste products such as carbon dioxide
diffuse from the body cells into the
tissue fluid and are reabsorbed backed
into the blood in the capillaries
next let's learn about the structure of
capillaries
capillaries are the smallest of blood
vessels that connect arteries and veins
capillaries carry both oxygenated and
deoxygenated blood
arteries divide further into narrower
vessels called arterioles which connect
to the capillaries
veins also divide further into narrower
vessels called venules which connect to
the capillaries
blood flows slowly in capillaries at low
pressure
the capillary walls are one cell thick
this means that substances can diffuse
in and out of them very easily
they have a very narrow Lumen just wide
enough for a red blood cell to pass
through
capillaries do not have valves
capillaries have very thin permeable
walls and this means that substances can
diffuse in and out of them very easily
it also means that blood plasma can leak
out and form tissue fluid at the
surrounding body cells thereby providing
a medium for the substances to diffuse
in
once again capillaries carry both
oxygenated and deoxygenated blood
blood flows slowly in capillaries
they have very thin walls just one cell
thick
they have a very narrow lumen
there are no valves in capillaries
and they have very thin permeable walls
you are expected to identify in diagrams
and images the main blood vessels to and
from the heart lungs kidneys and liver
a quick reminder blood is carried away
from the heart in arteries and towards
the heart in veins
the vena cava brings deoxygenated blood
from the body to the heart
the aorta carries oxygenated blood away
from the heart to the body
the pulmonary artery carries
deoxygenated blood away from the heart
to the lungs
the pulmonary vein carries oxygenated
blood to the heart from the lungs
the renal artery carries oxygenated
blood from the heart to the kidneys
the renal vein carries deoxygenated
blood from the kidneys to the heart
the hepatic artery brings oxygenated
blood from the heart to the liver
the hepatic vein brings deoxygenated
blood from the liver back to the heart
the hepatic portal vein transports
deoxygenated blood from the digestive
tract to the liver
moving on to blood
the components of blood are
red blood cells
white blood cells
platelets
and
plasma
red blood cells have a round flat shape
like a donut with an indentation in the
center but not a hole
this is called a biconcave disc shape
red blood cells don't have a nucleus so
as you can see in the photo micrograph
the circular shaped cells with a solid
color will be the red blood cells
white blood cells on the other hand are
larger cells with a big nucleus so on
the photomicrograph you may notice these
cells distinctly because of their big
nuclei
next let's learn the functions of the
components of blood
red blood cells transport oxygen
red blood cells contain a protein called
hemoglobin which binds to oxygen
allowing it to be transported around the
body to cells
white blood cells defend the body
against infections they fight off
infections by carrying out phagocytosis
and antibody production
platelets help in blood clotting
plasma transport blood cells ions
nutrients
urea hormones and carbon dioxide
there are two main types of white blood
cells
phagocytes and lymphocytes
phagocytes engulf pathogens by a process
called phagocytosis
so basically when a phagocyte comes
across a germ or a pathogen it engulfs
or surrounds it completely taking it
inwards
then it releases digestive enzymes on it
which digests the pathogen and destroys
it
a lymphocyte is a type of white blood
cell that produces antibodies to attack
and Destroy pathogens
you will also be expected to identify
phagocytes and lymphocytes in
photomicrographs and diagrams
phagocytes have a lobed nucleus and
granular cytoplasm
while lymphocytes have a large round
nucleus and clear non-granular cytoplasm
finally let's talk about blood clotting
when an injury takes place platelets
help prevent blood loss by forming blood
clots
platelets are fragments of cells present
in the blood
the platelets clamp together and form a
plug to stop the bleeding
this block at the cut also prevents
pathogens from entering the blood vessel
so during the blood clotting process the
protein fibrinogen is converted to
fibrin and insoluble protein to form a
mesh
more platelets stick to this mesh
forming a scab and thereby preventing
bleeding by blocking the cut
so that concludes part 2 of chapter 9
transport in animals
hope this video helped you thank you for
watching and please don't forget to
subscribe to IGCSE study buddy for more
biology revision videos bye
